intro: Cerasus avium var. melanocarpa, commonly known as the black cherry, is a species of Prunus native to North America. It is a deciduous shrub or small tree that typically grows to a height of 6–20 meters. The plant produces small, dark red to black berries that are edible when ripe, though they are often used in jams and preserves. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and have a serrated margin, while its flowers are white or pink and appear in clusters. The plant has a shallow root system and is adapted to a variety of soil types, making it a hardy and widespread species.
